dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 40% market drop? That seems like a pretty extreme prediction from this Kolanovic guy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A forty percent market drop? That seems like a pretty extreme prediction from this Kolanovic guy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kolanovic notes that if markets fall by 40% or more, for example, the Federal Reserve may need to take drastic action to prevent a depression.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, but he's not just pulling that number from thin air. He's pointing to the massive, uh, 2.2 trillion dollar shift into passive investing as a key vulnerability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, but he's not just pulling that number from thin air. He's pointing to the massive, uh, two point two trillion dollar shift into passive investing as a key vulnerability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The approximately $2 trillion shift from active to passive investing has removed individual buyers who can buy the market after significant price declines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But markets have had automated trading for years now. Why would it suddenly cause a 'Great Liquidity Crisis'?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But markets have had automated trading for years now. Why would it suddenly cause a 'Great Liquidity Crisis'?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Kolanovic explains as part of a 168 report issued earlier this month, a precipitous decline in stocks could cause the Great Liquidity Crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Because he argues that during a downturn, these quant funds are programmed to sell into weakness, not buy. They don't analyze value, they just follow the algorithm.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because he argues that during a downturn, these quant funds are programmed to sell into weakness, not buy. They don't analyze value, they just follow the algorithm.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Quant funds, he writes, are programmed to sell market weakness - rather than analyze fundamental valuation, for example.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So you're saying there's no one left to step in and be a buyer when things get rough?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So you're saying there's no one left to step in and be a buyer when things get rough?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. He notes that like, 91% of daily trading is from index and quant funds now. The individual stock picker who might see a bargain is largely gone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. He notes that like, ninety one percent of daily trading is from index and quant funds now. The individual stock picker who might see a bargain is largely gone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to Kolanovic, 90% of daily trading in the stock market is from index and quant funds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. And he ties this to the Federal Reserve potentially having to step in with extreme measures if things get that bad?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. And he ties this to the Federal Reserve potentially having to step in with extreme measures if things get that bad?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kolanovic notes that if markets fall by 40% or more, for example, the Federal Reserve may need to take drastic action to prevent a depression.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, purchasing equities or pushing for more tax cuts. It's a scenario where the usual tools might not be enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, purchasing equities or pushing for more tax cuts. It's a scenario where the usual tools might not be enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This would mean the Federal Reserve could purchase equities or attempt to stimulate the economy through additional tax cuts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But his timeline is vague—says maybe not until the first half of 2020, depending on trade wars and rate hikes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But his timeline is vague-says maybe not until the first half of twenty twenty, depending on trade wars and rate hikes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an interview with CNBC, Kolanovic said that while it's not possible to predict the timing of the next financial crisis, he doesn't see potential problems until the second half of 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, timing is always the hardest part. But the mechanics he's describing, the lack of human buyers in a crash... that part feels plausible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, timing is always the hardest part. But the mechanics he's describing, the lack of human buyers in a crash... that part feels plausible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the consumer debt angle—over a trillion in student loans alone. That's a lot of economic pressure if things go south.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the consumer debt angle-over a trillion in student loans alone. That's a lot of economic pressure if things go south.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the latest student loan debt statistics from Make Lemonade, there are over 44 million borrowers who collectively owe $1.5 trillion in student loan debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It adds another layer of fragility to the whole system. People might not have the capacity to spend their way out of a downturn.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It adds another layer of fragility to the whole system. People might not have the capacity to spend their way out of a downturn.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So his advice is basically... do nothing, sell, or hedge? Not exactly groundbreaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So his advice is basically... do nothing, sell, or hedge? Not exactly groundbreaking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While there are multiple options that you could consider, here are three potential strategies: 1. Do Nothing 2. Sell 3. Hedge

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's more about acknowledging the limits of prediction. You can't time it, so you pick a strategy based on your own risk tolerance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's more about acknowledging the limits of prediction. You can't time it, so you pick a strategy based on your own risk tolerance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I guess the put options hedge is the most proactive move if you're really worried.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I guess the put options hedge is the most proactive move if you're really worried.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One option is to buy S&P 500 put options to protect against a market decline.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though it costs you the premium if the crash doesn't happen. It's insurance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though it costs you the premium if the crash doesn't happen. It's insurance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the market doesn't drop, you lose the premium you paid for the put option.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you think though... is the system just built for faster, deeper crashes now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you think though... is the system just built for faster, deeper crashes now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's the central question. And Kolanovic's report suggests we might be about to find out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the central question. And Kolanovic's report suggests we might be about to find out.
